Search Home Departments Administration City Manager City Manager Staff Directory Eric Williams City Manager Email Phone: (352) 726-2611 ext 1002 Eric hails from southern Alabama and graduated from Mississippi State University earning a B.S. in Forestry and Land Management and Economics and a master’s degree in Biometrics & GIS. He began his work career in private land management in Jackson, MS. After working for five years in Mississippi and Alabama, he moved to Citrus County initially working for the Florida Division of Forestry as a Senior Forester managing a Geographic Information System (GIS), focusing on land management and wildland fire/disaster response. Eric was hired by Citrus County to be part of a development team to build a new Enterprise GIS system. He was promoted to the Director of Geographic Resources in Community Planning charged with directing and maintaining the county's long-range planning and GIS programs. In April 2013, he joined the City of Inverness as Assistant City Manager. Eric was promoted to City Manager on January 7, 2020. His experience in land management and planning have bolstered an environment desirous to increased investment and development. His deep involvement in the expansion of the Inverness Community Redevelopment Area, focus on streamlining the City’s development review process, and management and modernization of the City’s utilities has set the stage for many years of smart growth. This can be seen by many new and re-kindled developments such as Wyld Palms which had been idle for a number of years. He is a City resident and a former Rotarian but continues to enhance youth development programs within our city. Eric is Board Member of the Boys and Girls Club. He has brought forth art and cultural events for the community with a high focus on youth participation, bringing full utilization of the Valerie Theatre. To add to the many accomplishments, on January 21, 2025, the Mayor and Council proclaimed Eric the " City Manager of Distinction", celebrating his many achievements in serving the City of Inverness. Eric looks forward to the continued success of the community and is pleased to be part of its future. The Parks and Recreation Department enhances the quality of life for our community by providing safe, accessible, and inclusive parks, recreational facilities, and programs that promote physical, social, and mental well-being. We strive to preserve and protect our natural resources, promote environmental sustainability, and foster community engagement and social connections through recreational opportunities for all ages and abilities. Each user further certifies that it is understood that it is the candidate’s responsibility to independently verify any information received herein. Any use or reliance on the information contained in this document and these materials is at the sole risk of the user.  The City of Prattville, its officers, employees and agents hereby disclaim any responsibility or liability which may arise or result from the use or implementation of all or any portion of the advice or materials thereof included in this website, document, hyperlinks, message, and/or attachments. ✕ Cooters Pond Pavilion 1844 Cooters Pond Rd Prattville, AL 36067 ✕ Child's Place Playground Pavilion 460 Doster Road Prattville, AL 36067 ✕ Pratt Park Pavilion 460 Doster Road Prattville, AL 36067 ✕ Station 1- Archie Plyler Station one was renamed in honor of the late Fire Chief Archie Plyler. Chief Plyler began his career with the Prattville Fire Department in 1972 after retiring form a 20 year fire service career with the military. Chief Plyler progressed through the ranks and became the City’s Fire Marshal in 1979. In 1993 chief Plyler became the Fire chief and served in that capacity until he retired in 1996. The department made significant progress under his leadership and guidance and during his tenure the department acquired a new ladder truck and a new pumper. Chief Plyler also laid the ground work for a new fire station in Prattville East at 1904 Briarwood. ✕ Station 2- Herman Scott Station Two was renamed in honor of former Fire Chief Hermon Scott. Chief Scott began his career with the Prattville Fire Department in 1923 as a volunteer. He progressed through the ranks to chief in 1965 and became the first paid Chief of the Fire Department. The Fire Department made significant progress under Chief Scott’s leadership and guidance and during his tenure became a fully paid department and moved from the rear of the old City Hall to the Fire Station located at 942 East Main Street. Chief Scott served a total of forty-nine (49) years with the Prattville Fire Department ✕ Station 3 - George Donald McGough Station Three was named in honor of former Fire Chief Donald McGough who spent 38-1/2 years of dedicated service for the city of Prattville in the Fire Department; and 20 of those years were as Fire Chief. The department made significant progress and became renown for its progress state under his leadership, guidance and forethought including starting the first Medic transport service in the State and initiating the requirements necessary for lowering the city’s insurance rating from a class 7 to a class 4. Chief McGough was active and respected in numerous fire organizations including as President of the Alabama Association of Fire Chiefs and as State Director of the Southeast Fire Chiefs Association. ✕ Station 4 On March 19, 2021, the City of Prattville officially cut the ribbon to unveil the new Fire Station No. 4 and Police Annex. This $3.7 million Public Safety Facility is located on Old Ridge Road and will further enhance response times on the east side of Prattville. The Laney family generously donated the property for this site. Webb Builders, Inc. served as the general contractor on this project to construct the modern architectural design engineered by Civil Southeast Engineering Group. This station features state-of-the-art equipment, technology, living areas, a fueling station, and a workout room. James Hardie generously donated the fiber cement siding on the outside to provide an aesthetically pleasing finish that complements the surrounding area. This 12,814 square feet facility also houses Fire Engine 4 and the Police Mobile Command. ✕ Training Facility - Stanley E. Gann The Training Facility was named in honor of former Fire Chief Stanley Gann. Fire Chief Stanley Gann began his career with the Prattville Fire Department in 1981. Chief Gann spent 30 years of dedicated service to the City of Prattville with the last 14 years as Fire Chief. Under the command of Chief Gann the department made significant progress under his leadership and guidance. Chief Gann was instrumental in securing the land and relocating the Training Facility to where it is located today. Chief Gann continued to make training firefighters a priority with the purchase of a new 6 story drill tower. The building of a 2 story rope rescue tower and a new classroom. Chief Gann was dedicated to the training of firefighters and EMT's and with this dedication the Prattville Fire Department became the first Regional Training Center for the Alabama Fire College. The Training Facility now trains firefighters from across the United States. Chief Gann retired in 2011 and the Training Facility was renamed in his honor in 2012 to the Fire Chief Stanley Gann Training Facility ✕ Overlook Park Pavilion 299 Jay Street Prattville, AL 36067

Search Home Parks & Recreation City Parks Rentals Rentals The City of Inverness has many great locations to host your next event. Any and all organized events such as parties, reunions, weddings must obtain an event permit from the City of Inverness prior to the event. Venues within Liberty Park Depot Pavilion Downtown Valerie Theatre Valerie Plaza & Fountain Whispering Pines Park Pool Large Pavilion Recreation Building Green Shade Structure (located between the playground and Splash Pad) Yellow Shade Structure (located right outside the Splash Pad) To check availability on rentals & reserve, call (352) 726-3913. Whispering Pines Park Pavilion Located in the Family Center of the park close to the Splash pad, the playground, ballfields and trails. The rental fee is $75  for either time slot, 9 am to 1 pm or 2 pm – 6 pm. Capacity is approximately 50 people.  Contact Park Administration at (352) 726-3913 for more information. Whispering Pines Recreation Building Located in the front section of the park and is air conditioned/heated for convenience.  The facility does not have a full kitchen however counter, sink and several electrical units can do the job.  Tables and chairs are part of the rental facility. The rental fee is $25 per hour.   Capacity is approximately 50 people. Contact Park Administration at (352) 726-3913 for more information. Whispering Pines Aquatic Facility Located in the back section of the park and boast a 25-meter Junior Olympic size pool. Private pool rentals at Whispering Pines Park are available only during June, July, and August. Rentals are limited to a 2-hour period, with a $150 fee for up to 25 people on the deck. Reservations are available on Sundays from 3:00 PM to 5:00 PM. Parties over 25 people require an extra Lifeguard and is an additional $25 fee. Contact the Park Administration at (352) 726-3913 for more information. Private Pool Rental Rules Only Coast Guard approved life vests are allowed at the pool, no swimmies, snorkles or floats are allowed.  You may bring food, drinks and a cake for your party.  A covered area is provided for serving food.  No food or drinks (except bottled water) are allowed on the pool deck or in the pool at any time. Depot Pavilion Located in the Depot District beside Liberty Park.  The pavilion is available for large events and has the capacity for approximately 200 guests.  There is a flat fee of $250.  Contact Sherry Bechtel at (352) 726-2611 extension 1303 for details. Due to the popularity of these facilities, it is recommended you call first for availability and then complete the reservation form below, to secure your request. There are fees associated with reserving the facility of your choice. The more advanced notice, the better we can serve you. Facility Reservation Form Requests to reserve the facilities can be done online or via paper. If the paper method is preferred, you can mail the form to the City of Inverness. Attn: Parks Department, 212 W. Main Street Inverness, FL 34450 , or email . After review of your request, staff will contact you regarding the status of your reservation and any applicable fees that may apply. Cooter Pond Park | Discover Crystal River Skip to content CRYSTAL RIVER HOMOSASSA INVERNESS FLORAL CITY 76 ° MENU Search Term Search CRYSTAL RIVER HOMOSASSA INVERNESS FLORAL CITY Things to Do Events Where to Stay Dining Cities & Neighborhoods Plan Your Visit AR Experience Meeting Planners Citrus County Partners In Tourism Media Contact Us Visitors Guide Blog Email Signup Deals Facebook Instagram Twitter YouTube Pinterest Save Cooter Pond Park Cooter Pond is named for the Florida Cooter Pond Turtles that are abundant in this scenic City of Inverness Park with an amazing network of boardwalks that take you right over the water. Below Limpkins feast on apple snails and Gallinules fledge their young. The foot path that leads around the pond to the Withacoochee State Trail and Lake Henderson is full of suprises for the attentive birder. Reviews Cooter Pond Park Gallery 181 Hwy 41 S Inverness,

ONLINE PORTAL BUILDING PERMIT APPLICATIONS: The Building permit application must be submitted with the property owner and contractor signatures when using the portal. Search Home Parks & Recreation City Parks Park Rules Park Rules City of Inverness Park Rules Park hours of operation are Sunrise to Sunset No alcoholic beverages No tents, tables, or grills allowed in park unless permitted by the City for an event Organized gatherings such as parties, reunions, etc. must obtain an event permit from the City prior to event No solicitation or handbill distribution Dogs must always be kept on a leash and under the owner’s effective control. Owners are responsible to pick up after their pet Children must be supervised by adults No overnight parking, RV parking, or camping No barbecues or fires allowed unless in designated areas No glass containers No metal detecting No motorized vehicles unless authorized Do not feed the alligators No sleeping on benches, tables, or other park amenities Use park amenities for their intended purposes Fighting, cursing, and other behaviors deemed inappropriate are prohibited and are grounds for removal from the parks. Please report any vandalism or incidents to Park Staff at 352-726-3913 Pursuant to City Ordinance 14.5 Park Use Permit may be obtained by calling City of Inverness 352-726-3913 All city, state and federal ordinances, rules and laws apply Staff Directory Woody Worley Director of Parks and Recreation Email More Information Sherry Bechtel Assistant Director of Parks and Recreation Email More Information Bike Inverness Cycling Etiquette Cycling Groups Cycling Itineraries Inverness Biking Resources Inverness Depot District Inverness Trailhead and Connectors Withlacoochee State Trail Cooter Pond Park The Depot District Liberty Park & Depot District Liberty Trail Market at the Depot Neighborhood Parks Bryant Park Hillcrest Park Mossy Oak Park White Lake Park Park Rules Park Events Rentals Hold an Event in Inverness Wallace Brooks Park Whispering Pines Park Whispering Pines Pool Whispering Pines Splash Park Whispering Pines Park Trails Recreation Building - User Groups Council Meetings & Agendas Notify Me Employment Bill Pay Business Directory Forms & Permits City Council & Mayor Learn More...
